Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Investigation of Environmental Effects on the Fatigue Degradation Properties in Metallic Nanostructures
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY

The goal of the proposed research is to gain a fundamental understanding on the fatigue degradation properties of metallic nanostructures in non-inert environments. The specific research objectives of the proposed research are to develop an experimental technique using microelectromechanical system (MEMS) devices to accurately measure the fatigue properties of nanostructures in non-inert environments and to investigate the size and environmental effects on the stress-life fatigue curves and fatigue crack growth rates in metallic nanostructures. The novelty of the approach is to use electrical (resistance) measurements to infer structural changes, such as cracking, without the need for in-situ SEM/TEM capability (testing will instead take place in an environmental chamber).

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This research will address unexplored reliability issues regarding the use of metallic nanostructures in nanoscale devices; such issues may ultimately limit their successful commercialization. A thorough understanding of the degradation properties and their dependence on size and environment is fundamental to ensure proper structural reliability of devices fabricated with emerging nanotechnologies. The educational broad impact of the proposed research lies in the opportunities to promote motivation, learning and academic success of high school students from underrepresented groups in the fields of Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM), and to develop the teaching skills of high school teachers. The PI intends to develop, with high school teachers, a summer enrichment program dedicated to the fracture of engineering materials and targeted for high school students in grades 9 and 10.

ProgramReference.Text: RET SUPP-Res Exp for Tchr Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
This EAGER grant focused on the development of a novel experimental technique dedicated to measuring the fatigue properties of nanomaterials under various environments. Studying the degradation properties of nanomaterials is critical to ensure the reliability of components fabricated with emerging technologies, such as microeletromechanical system (MEMS) technology and nanotechnology. One of the challenges was to fabricate a testing machine capable of 1) applying cycling deformation to nanomaterials, and 2) measuring the resulting behavior in various environments, until failure occurs.

 

We developed a micron-scale testing machine (see Fig. 1), fabricated with MEMS technology. Nanospecimens are manipulated and placed onto the machine using a nanomanipulator. The machine applies a displacement based on thermal actuation (the beams of the thermal actuator are heated by passing a current, resulting in an expansion of the beams and therefore a displacement). Part of that displacement goes into the nanospecimen, and part goes into the load sensing beams. If we can measure the displacement going into the nanospecimen and load sensor, we know the resulting deformation of the specimen. This is achieved thanks to two capacitive sensors placed on each sides of the specimen. By measuring tiny changes in capacitance between the two capacitive sensors, we can calculate the applied stress and strain of the nanospecimen. The novelty of this experimental technique is that the nanospecimen deformation is measured electrically, whereas previous techniques relied on high magnification images in electron microscopes, requiring a vacuum environment. Hence, our machine can be used to measure the degradation properties in various environments (air at different temperatures and humidity levels, as well as vacuum).

 

We demonstrated that our MEMS-based nanotensile testing setup can be used to measure the fatigue properties of nanocrystalline nanobeams. Fatigue tests can be performed for a wide range of maximum applied stresses and strains, frequencies (up to ~0.25-1Hz with the thermal-actuator-based MEMS devices), and environment. The developed experimental technique will be used in future research to investigate the surface fatigue crack initiation mechanisms in nanocrystalline metals. Particularly, the technique will allow the monitoring of cyclic plasticity and the measurement of initiation fatigue life on the nanocrystalline nanobeams, as a function of maximum plastic strain, frequency and environment. The technique will also be used to perform quantitative in-situ transmission electron microscopy fatigue experiments to identify the fatigue crack initiation mechanisms.


Last Modified: 08/29/2011
Modified by: Olivier N Pierron

Image
  • Scanning electron microscope images of the micron-scale testing machine used for measuring the fatigue properties of nanoscale materials
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This EAGER grant focused on the development of a novel experimental technique dedicated to measuring the fatigue properties of nanomaterials under various environments. Studying the degradation properties of nanomaterials is critical to ensure the reliability of components fabricated with emerging technologies, such as microeletromechanical system (MEMS) technology and nanotechnology. One of the challenges was to fabricate a testing machine capable of 1) applying cycling deformation to nanomaterials, and 2) measuring the resulting behavior in various environments, until failure occurs. We developed a micron-scale testing machine (see Fig. 1), fabricated with MEMS technology. Nanospecimens are manipulated and placed onto the machine using a nanomanipulator. The machine applies a displacement based on thermal actuation (the beams of the thermal actuator are heated by passing a current, resulting in an expansion of the beams and therefore a displacement). Part of that displacement goes into the nanospecimen, and part goes into the load sensing beams. If we can measure the displacement going into the nanospecimen and load sensor, we know the resulting deformation of the specimen. This is achieved thanks to two capacitive sensors placed on each sides of the specimen. By measuring tiny changes in capacitance between the two capacitive sensors, we can calculate the applied stress and strain of the nanospecimen. The novelty of this experimental technique is that the nanospecimen deformation is measured electrically, whereas previous techniques relied on high magnification images in electron microscopes, requiring a vacuum environment. Particularly, the technique will allow the monitoring of cyclic plasticity and the measurement of initiation fatigue life on the nanocrystalline nanobeams, as a function of maximum plastic strain, frequency and environment. The technique will also be used to perform quantitative in-situ transmission electron microscopy fatigue experiments to identify the fatigue crack initiation mechanisms.
